snippet: These inequities compared with white students are similar to those in traditional public schools, but charter suspension rates are slightly higher.
abstract: Analysis of federal education data carried out by nonprofit Center for Civil Rights and Remedies reveals black students are four times more likely than white students to be suspended from charter schools; study also finds students with disabilities are suspended at rate two to three times higher than those without; findings, which mirror those in public schools, are likely to provoke debate over charter schools.
lead_paragraph: These inequities compared with white students are similar to those in traditional public schools, but charter suspension rates are slightly higher.

headline.main: Charter Schools Suspend Black and Disabled Students More, Study Says
headline.print_headline: Disparities in Discipline Found in Charter Schools
